properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect from late this afternoon through Sunday morning. Lake effect flurries are expected to develop late this afternoon off Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. The activity should intensify this evening with a threat of snow squalls. Some areas may see snowfall amounts of 10 cm by Sunday morning. In addition, northwest winds gusting up to 50 km/h may result in areas of blowing snow giving reduced visibility. The lake effect activity is expected to diminish Sunday morning. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T07:49:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T15:50:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2814120769.2020
Area: Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County, Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Listowel - Milverton - Northern Perth County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A southwest flow of moist and unstable air will continue to impact the Coquihalla Highway between Hope and Merritt this weekend. Heaviest accumulations are expected today with amounts of up to 15 cm. A further snowfall of 5 to 10 cm will occur tonight and again on Sunday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T05:01:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T13:02:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1807040876.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds over southwest Saskatchewan beginning Saturday afternoon. A low pressure system will bring strong westerly winds, with gusts up to 90 km/h, into southwestern Saskatchewan Saturday afternoon and propagate east throughout the evening. Winds will improve overnight Saturday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T02:39:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T10:40:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3841149875.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and wind expected beginning Sunday afternoon. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Stronger coastal gusts possible. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across eastern Newfoundland Sunday afternoon. Strong winds and blowing snow will develop overnight Sunday and continue into Monday morning. Snow and blowing snow will result in poor visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Conditions are expected to improve near noon Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-04T18:24:14-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong winter storm is giving significant winds to the west coast of Vancouver Island. Southeast winds at 80 km/h for exposed sections of West Vancouver Island, will shift to westerly this evening and ease overnight. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme windchill values of -50 to -55 are expected through the weekend. Some moderation may occur during the day. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h beginning Sunday evening with stronger coastal gusts possible. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: 2 to 5 cm of snow can be expected across southeastern Newfoundland Sunday afternoon. The snow will become heavy in the evening with significant accumulations expected. Strong winds and blowing snow will develop Sunday evening and continue into Monday morning. Snow and blowing snow will result in poor visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Conditions are expected to improve near noon Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-05T06:14:04-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system will spread heavy snow across central Manitoba beginning this afternoon. The snow will taper off from west to east through Sunday. Many areas will see 10 to 20 cm of snow over a 24 hour period with the highest accumulations along a line from Pukatawagan to Norway House. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected on Sunday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm, possibly higher over parts of the eastern mainland and Cape Breton Time span: Before dawn Sunday morning into Sunday night. Location: all of Nova Scotia Remarks: A disturbance will approach the Maritimes later tonight and spread snow to much of the province Sunday. In the west and along parts of the Atlantic coast, the precipitation will start as rain and then change to snow early Sunday morning. At this time, the highest amounts are expected over eastern sections of the province where the snow will persist into the evening. General snowfall amounts of 5 to 15 cm are expected, with locally higher amounts possible over eastern regions. However, should the intensity or track of this system shift from what is currently expected, these amounts could change. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop later on Sunday, especially over the eastern half of the province, and combine with the fresh snow to create reduced visibility in blowing snow. The combination of snow and blowing snow could impact travel in parts of the province later on Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T06:55:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T14:56:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1692564648.2020
